snippet: The Afghan Army is so plagued with desertions and low re-enlistment rates that it has to replace a third of its entire force every year, officials say.
abstract: Afghan National Army is so plagued with desertions and low re-enlistment rates that it has to replace a third of its entire force every year; Afghan deserters complain of corruption among their officers, poor food and equipment, indifferent medical care, Taliban intimidation of their families, and, probably most troubling, lack of belief in army's ability to fight insurgents after American military withdraws.

byline.contributor: Jawad Sukhanyar and Habib Zahori contributed reporting from Kabul, and employees of The New York Times from Khost, Kunar, Kunduz and Kandahar Provinces.

lead_paragraph: The Afghan Army is so plagued with desertions and low re-enlistment rates that it has to replace a third of its entire force every year, officials say.

headline.seo: Afghan Army’s High Turnover Clouds U.S. Exit Plan
headline.main: Afghan Army’s Turnover Threatens U.S. Strategy
headline.print_headline: Turnover Clouds Afghan Military As U.S. Plans Exit
